The Future of PMM

Issue #1
Friday, February 14, 2026
Friday Note

Welcome to the first Friday Note of The Future of PMM ‚Äî a resource for our team as we look to scale with AI. The site has lots of great resources to help you learn more about AI and how it's transforming our jobs as product marketers.

Great news: We have an official budget to invest in AI tools for our team. We'll be making those decisions with your input ‚Äî so please take a few minutes to complete the surveys below. Your feedback directly shapes what we buy and how we roll it out.

This week I also sat down with David Yockelson, a Research VP and Gartner Fellow who leads Gartner's product marketing practice. His Defend / Extend / Upend framework is the clearest way I've seen to think about where and how to deploy AI across PMM activities. More on that in future issues.

üì¨ Know someone who'd find this useful? Forward this email or have them subscribe here.

‚ÄîChris

Action Required

Gartner Product Marketing Skills Assessment

As Dan mentioned, we've partnered with Gartner to conduct a brief, anonymous skills assessment that benchmarks our function against other technology organizations.

The assessment covers 18 product marketing activities across five core areas:

Understanding the market Knowing your audience Communicating value Enabling GTM teams Managing PMM teams

This is not a performance review or individual evaluation, so please be open with your responses ‚Äî it will help us calibrate and identify the PMM capability training we need to provide.

üìã Your Privacy Is Protected

  • Individual responses are anonymous ‚Äî we will not see who selected which answers
  • Gartner will only know if someone participated, not your individual responses
  • Your input directly informs our priorities for capability development, tooling, and enablement

You should have received an email from Gartner yesterday inviting you to complete the Product Marketing Score assessment. Please take the time to complete it if you haven't already.

News Roundup

What Happened This Week

01

Matt Shumer's Viral Essay: "Something Big Is Happening"

The HyperWrite CEO's 5,000-word essay comparing AI's current moment to February 2020 is everywhere this week. His thesis: we're in the "this seems overblown" phase of something much bigger than COVID. The piece resonates because Shumer isn't making predictions ‚Äî he's describing what already happened to AI workers and warning everyone else they're next.

Read it ‚Üí
02

SAP Joule Studio Goes GA with Agent Builder

SAP's Joule Studio agent builder is now generally available, letting teams build custom AI agents on BTP with support for frameworks like CrewAI and LangGraph. This is the infrastructure layer for Upend-tier transformations.

Read more ‚Üí
03

Anthropic's Claude Gets Persistent Memory

Claude Pro and Max users can now enable memory that persists across conversations ‚Äî no more re-explaining your projects, preferences, or context. For PMMs using Claude for ongoing work, this is a significant workflow upgrade.

Learn more ‚Üí
04

LinkedIn Accelerate: AI-Powered Campaign Manager

LinkedIn's AI features now automatically adjust bidding, placement, and creative delivery to maximize campaign objectives. Another example of Extend-tier automation arriving in B2B marketing.

Explore ‚Üí
05

Salesforce Agentforce Comes to Marketing Cloud

Agentforce actions are now available in Marketing Cloud Account Engagement, helping manage prospects and nurture campaigns from anywhere in Salesforce. Cross-functional GTM orchestration is here.

Read more ‚Üí
